title: 105_hr1258
content: The "Job Opportunity and Welfare Reduction Act of 1997" includes a pilot program to place welfare recipients in jobs left vacant by unauthorized aliens. The Attorney General will conduct a pilot program to notify states of job opportunities for welfare recipients resulting from the removal of unauthorized aliens or issuance of unauthorized work letters. The program must be implemented by October 1, 1998, and will end after a 4-year period. The Attorney General will operate a pilot program in states receiving grants under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. The program will notify employers of unauthorized aliens removed from work sites or issued unauthorized work letters. The Attorney General will notify employers of unauthorized aliens removed from work sites or issued unauthorized work letters, including details on the positions held, industry, skilled or unskilled work, location of work site, and number of unauthorized aliens. The deadline for the notice submission is 8 days after the removal or entry onto the work site by a Service officer. The Act defines terms such as "Service," "State," "unauthorized alien," and "unauthorized work letter" for clarity and enforcement purposes. The Attorney General notifies an employer about a possible unauthorized alien worker. SEC. 3. BONUS TO REWARD PARTICIPATING STATES. Amendment to Section 403(a)(4) of the Social Security Act regarding state performance measurement and bonus rewards for high performing immigration pilot program States. After the enactment of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996, the Secretary will develop a formula with input from the National Governors' Association and the American Public Welfare Association to measure State performance in operating the funded program. Additionally, within 6 months of the Job Opportunity and Welfare Reduction Act of 1997, the Secretary will consult with the National Governors' Association for immigration pilot program states. The Secretary, in consultation with the National Governors' Association and the American Public Welfare Association, will develop a formula to measure the performance of immigration pilot program States in placing adults receiving assistance in employment vacancies resulting from the removal of unauthorized aliens by Immigration and Naturalization Service officers. The Secretary will develop a formula to measure state performance in placing adults in employment vacancies resulting from the removal of unauthorized aliens. This includes scoring states and setting performance thresholds for bonus years. The Secretary will develop a formula to measure state performance in placing adults in employment vacancies resulting from the removal of unauthorized aliens. This includes setting performance thresholds for bonus years to ensure specific grant amounts are met. The Secretary will develop a formula to measure state performance in placing adults in employment vacancies resulting from the removal of unauthorized aliens. This includes setting performance thresholds for bonus years to reward immigration pilot program States based on their performance in the preceding fiscal year. The eligible State operating the pilot program under the Job Opportunity and Welfare Reduction Act of 1997 must provide a list of job vacancies to employers after receiving a notice from the Attorney General. The State operating the pilot program must provide a list of job vacancies to employers and submit a report to the Secretary for performance evaluation. The State's performance under subparagraph (C)(ii) will be evaluated. The amendments made by subsection (a) will take effect on July 1, 1998, or the date of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress within 3 months after the pilot program ends, detailing the program's success in providing job referrals and making recommendations on reauthorization, expansion, and improvements.
